name: Maximum Size Subarray Sum Equals k

similar_questions.title: Maximum Beauty of an Array After Applying Operation
Shortest Subarray With OR at Least K II

title: Maximum Size Subarray Sum Equals k
content:
Given an integer array nums and an integer k, return the maximum length of a subarray that sums to k. If there is not one, return 0 instead.

 

Example 1:

Input: nums = [1,-1,5,-2,3], k = 3
Output: 4
Explanation: The subarray [1, -1, 5, -2] sums to 3 and is the longest.

Example 2:

Input: nums = [-2,-1,2,1], k = 1
Output: 2
Explanation: The subarray [-1, 2] sums to 1 and is the longest.

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= nums.length <= 2 * 105
  • -104 <= nums[i] <= 104
  • -109 <= k <= 109

discussion_posts.name: purplebeth
discussion_posts.content: I\'ve noticed a lot of these problems with subarrays equal to / greater than / less than a target generally use one of 1 strategies for the optimal solution - either a sliding window with 2 pointers or a hashmap storing cumulative sum. I have trouble deciding between the two at times - any suggestions on how to determine which is the most appropriate approach?\n\nOne idea I had is that if the given list is all positive or negative, then you can use sliding window, but if you don\'t know the sign of the numbers, better to use a hashmap since you cannot anticipate what expanding/contracting a window might do?

discussion_posts.name: new2500
discussion_posts.content:
The questions states(on June/17):
>Given an array nums and a target value k, find the maximum length of a subarray that sums to k. If there isn't one, return 0 instead.

Beware of the definition of "subarray", subarray don't have to be continuous.[What is difference between subarray and contiguous subarray?](https://www.quora.com/What-is-difference-between-subarray-and-contiguous-subarray)

I tried test case: [1,-2,3], 4.

The top-voted solution and the OJ both return 0, rather than 2 ({1,3}).
![0_1496536668876_捕获.JPG](/assets/uploads/files/1496536675119-捕获-resized.jpg) 

Let's assume the question take non-continuous subarray into account, any idea on solving the non-continuous subarray case? It seems that O(N) time is hard.

Thanks in advance.

discussion_posts.name: touchdown
discussion_posts.content:
In the problem statement, it says:

Example 2:
Given nums = [-2, -1, 2, 1], k = 1,
return 2. (because the subarray [-1, 2] sums to 1 and is the longest)

Shouldn't it return 3 instead of 2?  For me, [-2, 2, 1] is apparently the max subarray.

discussion_posts.name: nedimsahin
discussion_posts.content:
If you are struggling to understand how the O(n) solution (hasmap) implemented for this problem, I'd recommend studying the "Subarray Sum Equals K" problem first:

https://leetcode.com/problems/subarray-sum-equals-k/solution/#

The content and slide in the Approach #4 helps a lot to understand the solution
![image](https://s3-lc-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/users/nedimsahin/image_1528600395.png)

discussion_posts.name: rajhivthirumal
discussion_posts.content: From the question is it assumed that the subarray is a contiguous sub-array?

discussion_posts.name: nlackx
discussion_posts.content: Given `S[i]` a partial sum that starts at position`0` and ends at`i`, what can `S[i - k]` tell you ?\n\nIt should be "what does `S[i] - k` tell you?"

discussion_posts.name: edgardowardo
discussion_posts.content: If [2. Two Sum](https://leetcode.com/problems/two-sum/description/), Hash Map, Prefix Sum had a throuple and a love child.

discussion_posts.name: AndriiShmerchuk
discussion_posts.content: I had this question on my interview in Amazon as L4 SDE in 2024.\nI didn\'t solve it (I just said I can do brute force) and didn\'t get that offer and now when i found this problem on LC i solved it in ca 20 min

discussion_posts.name: etuan
discussion_posts.content:
I think the following example is wrong. It should be 3 because the longest list [-2, 2, 1].

Example 2:

Input: nums = [-2,-1,2,1], k = 1
Output: 2
Explanation: The subarray [-1, 2] sums to 1 and is the longest.
